7e50fd0d5e4848e59c9a8a6a627717c9:
Egyptian security forces killed a gunman suspected of shooting dead a policeman near St Catherine's monastery in the Sinai Peninsula.
Three other officers were wounded in Tuesday's attack in South Sinai province at a checkpoint near the ancient site.
Daesh claimed the shooting, which the ministry said Tuesday was carried out by "a number of gunmen".
Security forces in South Sinai, in cooperation with bedouin elements, tracked the perpetrators' escape route and closed roads that would be used to escape.
The suspect began firing after he was found by security forces, "which required the forces to quickly deal with him, injuring him leading to his death."
Security staff found an automatic weapon and ammunition, adding that "investigations are ongoing to identify the terrorist."
Tuesday's attack comes nine days after Palm Sunday services at Coptic Christian churches in the cities of Tanta and Alexandria were struck by twin bomb attacks claimed by Daesh, killing 45 people.
Daesh has threatened to carry out more attacks on Copts, which makes up about 10 percent of Egypt's population of more than 90 million people.
Egypt has battled an extremist insurgency in North Sinai province that has killed hundreds of policemen and troops since the 2013 ouster of Islamist president Mohammad Mursi.
In October 2015, Daesh claimed the bombing of a Russian airliner carrying holidaymakers from the popular South Sinai resort of Sharm Al Shaikh, killing all 224 people on board.
3fa410c890975d21e5fbbb783e8cff68:
The Islamic State (IS) militant group claimed responsibility for an attack on Egypt's St Catherine's security checkpoint late Tuesday.
The attack killed at least one policeman and injured four others.
The attack on the famous monastery and one of the most prominent tourist hotspots in South Sinai comes nearly one week after the country was hit with twin deadly bombings on Coptic Orthodox cathedrals.
The IS group claimed responsibility for last week’s attacks.
Cairo has imposed an extendable nationwide three-month state of emergency and deployed the armed forces to aid police in protecting vital institutions.
8a8d508dd279c853935449cff93e1748:
Armed men attacked Egyptian security forces near the St. Catherine Monastery in Sinai Peninsula, killing one police officer and wounding four more.
Daesh terrorist group claimed responsibility for the attack on the security checkpoint, which is situated some 800 meters from the monastery.
The incident comes just over one week after the Takfiri terrorist group claimed responsibility for two deadly bombings on Christian churches in Egypt.
On April 9, at least 17 people were killed and more than 40 injured after a bomb targeted a church in Alexandria.
At least 27 people were killed and around 80 others wounded after a church in the city of Tanta near Cairo was targeted with a remote-controlled bomb.
Egyptian police have arrested a man allegedly involved in the church bombings, Ali Mahmoud Mohamed Hassan.
Egyptian officials arrested 13 people suspected of planning attacks on the country’s minority Christians as well as security forces.
49ae928c56a8f2afa90374ef5b220cdd:
The Egyptian military killed a senior Daesh cleric and 18 terrorists in air strikes in the Sinai Peninsula.

The military has killed several of their top leaders, but the extremists have increasingly expanded their attacks from the Sinai to other parts of Egypt, especially against Christians.
Daesh, which claimed the shooting, has threatened more attacks on Coptic Christians, who make up about 10 per cent of Egypt’s population of more than 90 million people.

47efa672c09fc8ff6d3ba9d29870edbc:
A leaked video broadcast by Mekameleen TV shows the Egyptian army extrajudicially executing prisoners in Sinai in December 2016.
The Egyptian army announced that terrorists had been killed after the execution video was leaked.
The US provides Cairo with $1.3 billion annually.
Egyptian security forces have carried out other extrajudicial killings in Sinai.
Human Rights Watch concluded that security forces in Egypt may have arbitrarily detained and forcibly disappeared up to 10 men and then staged a raid to cover up their killings.
The Egyptian military said that air raids in the Sinai had killed 19 members of Daesh, three of them prominent members of the group.
a9eb31b4276d2509a158acc601d453cb:
Egyptian military forces in the northern Sinai Peninsula executed at least two and as many as eight unarmed detainees and covered up the killings to make it appear that the victims were armed "terrorists" shot to death in a raid, Human Rights Watch said today.
Video of the killings aired by an opposition television channel based in Turkey on April 20, 2017, appears to show a man in a camouflage uniform executing the two men, one after the other, with an assault rifle.
The video also appears to show a member of Egypt's military intelligence service observing and directing the first execution and that the soldiers used Humvee vehicles supplied by the United States to transport the detainees.
Sinai News 24, an independent Facebook page that tracks events in the Sinai Peninsula, reported that the two victims were brothers from the Rumailat clan – Daoud Sabri al-Awabdah, 16, and Abd al-Hadi Sabri al-Awabdah, 19 – whom the army had arrested in the town of Rafah and forcibly disappeared on July 18, 2016.
In a third video of the scene, also posted on the same pro-government Facebook page, a man can be heard saying, "Should I change the position of the gun?" The man who is filming the body replies, "Finish, finish."
Two North Sinai sources told Human Rights Watch that the man seen executing both victims is a member of a local militia, colloquially called Group 103, which was formed by the Egyptian military in 2015 to assist in Sinai operations and which the military arms and oversees.
In the execution video, the militia member appears to be wearing an Egyptian army infantry patch on his shoulder. A second man in the video appears to be wearing a patch of the armed forces' Military Intelligence and Reconnaissance Department.
Since the military removed former President Mohamed Morsy in July 2013, violence has significantly increased in North Sinai, an underdeveloped and long-marginalized governorate that borders Israel and Gaza.
In response, Egypt has deployed more forces to the Sinai than at any time since the country's 1973 war with Israel.
The counterterrorism campaign in North Sinai has been rife with abuses. Between July 2013 and August 2015, Egyptian authorities destroyed around half of the town of Rafah, on the border with the Gaza Strip, evicting thousands of families and demolishing at least 3,255 buildings.
In January 2017, Interior Ministry counterterrorism troops most likely executed at least four and as many as 10 North Sinai men whom they had previously arrested. The Interior Ministry then apparently staged a fake raid to cover up the incident.
The killings shown in the video that surfaced on April 20 fit a pattern described by several North Sinai residents. At least two detainees formerly held by the army told Human Rights Watch that their guards would come at dawn, summon certain detainees, and take them away without telling them where they were going. These detainees did not return, said the former prisoners, who said they believed the men had been executed.
c9e75c8b151adbfde6ec8b0018e8f0c0:
A police officer was killed and two policemen were injured when an improvised explosive device detonated in North Sinai’s El-Arish city.
The bomb killed 51-year-old first lieutenant Ahmed El-Sayed Ahmed from Beni Suef governorate, and injured 46-year-old police corporal Ahmed Ali Ibrahim and 21-year-old conscript Mohamed Fatouh.
Egypt’s army and police forces have been battling for several years a militant Islamist insurgency in North Sinai centered in the cities of El-Arish, Rafah and Sheikh Zuweid, with hundreds killed on both sides.
c278125d91d5e8a88ef54eb3cc4133b4:
Members of a prominent local tribe in northern Sinai burned alive a suspected Daesh militant.
The charred body of the suspected Daesh militant was found early on Wednesday south the town of Rafah in the Sinai Peninsula.
The killing came just hours after an Daesh suicide bomber attacked a tribal checkpoint in northern Sinai and killed four members of the Tarabeen tribe on Tuesday.
The incident is the latest escalation in the conflict in the restive peninsula, where Egyptian forces have been battling a growing insurgency with local tribes mostly remaining on the sidelines.
e51ff556d0e6a183e0176a338f17d8da:
Militants in Egypt killed three police officers and wounded five others in a drive-by shooting in Cairo.
Assailants armed with machine guns opened fire on a police patrol stationed at an intersection in the eastern neighborhood of Nasr City overnight.
Police fired back and began pursuing the cars "in an effort to apprehend the perpetrators."
No group has claimed responsibility for the incident.
The attack is the latest in hundreds of attacks on soldiers and policemen since the 2013 military overthrow of elected Islamist president Mohammed Morsi.
Much of the violence targeting security forces has been concentrated in the northern Sinai province, where Egypt is fighting an insurgency by a local affiliate of the so-called "Islamic State" (IS) group.
Similar assaults have also been carried out by another group known as Hasm, or "Decisiveness," which the government suspects is linked to the banned Muslim Brotherhood.
While attacks in Cairo have been relatively rare, extremist militants have increasingly sought to expand their campaign from the Sinai Peninsula to other parts of the country.
Egypt has been under a state of emergency since April 10 after two suicide bombings at Christian churches in Tanta and Alexandria killed at least 45 people.
IS claimed both attacks, which were described as being among the bloodiest the country had experienced in years.
520b47dd998dbd868b01a53ca3e1168d:
Unidentified gunmen attacked an Egyptian police convoy near Cairo, killing three officers and wounding five others.
The attack occurred around 11:45 p.m. Monday when gunmen in two vehicles approached a moving security convoy.
Police returned fire at the attackers’ vehicles and are pursuing them to apprehend the perpetrators.
Egypt has been fighting an insurgency by a local affiliate of the Islamic State group in North Sinai province.
Hundreds of soldiers and policemen have been killed in the insurgency since the army overthrew Islamist president Mohamed Morsi in 2013.
President Abdel Fattah el-Sissi declared a three-month state of emergency on April 10 following deadly church bombings last month.
IS claimed responsibility for the church bombings in Tanta and Alexandria on April 9 that killed 45 people.
The military has killed several of the group’s top leaders, but the jihadists have increasingly expanded their attacks from Sinai to other parts of Egypt, including Cairo.

7545370f93063c1282742dab18be3272:
The Holocaust and the creation of Israel are two distinct events, and linking them is historically false and morally repugnant.
The Balfour Declaration, the Allied victory in World War I, and the growth of the Yishuv in Palestine were key factors in the creation of Israel, independent of the Holocaust.
The Yishuv's military strength and the failure of Rommel's Afrika Corps and Hitler's Army Group South to reach Palestine saved the Yishuv during World War II.
Britain's withdrawal from Palestine was due to its colonial exhaustion and not the Holocaust.
The UN vote on partition was based on self-interest, with Russia, France, and the US supporting Israel for geopolitical reasons.
The survivors of the Holocaust played a limited role in the establishment of Israel, as most were stranded in Europe and the British blockade prevented large-scale immigration.
The narrative that the Holocaust was necessary for the creation of Israel is false and morally wrong.
88182b52ea864e16cb32149d7b483838:
Israel will celebrate the 69th anniversary of its independence on May 2 and the 50th anniversary of the Six-Day War on June 5.
In the Six-Day War, Israel conquered the Sinai Peninsula, the Golan Heights and the West Bank and liberated East Jerusalem.
Israel's population has grown from fewer than 3 million citizens in 1967 to almost 9 million today.
Israel is one of the strongest nuclear powers in the world and leads the world in cybertechnology and high-tech.
Israel's immediate existential threats have been lifted, with peace agreements signed with Egypt and Jordan and Iran's nuclear project on hold.
Israel is facing internal divisions and social unrest, with political divisions posing a real threat.
Israel has yet to decide what it wants from itself and what to do with the West Bank and the approximately 2 million Palestinians living there.
A growing group of religious Israelis demand the annexation of the West Bank, while another group still believes in a two-state solution.
US President Donald Trump could have a dramatic impact on Israel's future.
8e2103c3c0a4c053214f0ba805a7da09:
In 1800, the Jewish population was 7000; in 1920, 50,000; in 1948, 650,000; and in 2017, nearly 6,500,000.
Israel is considered the eighth superpower in the world militarily, when it had only a makeshift army in 1948.
The birth rate of Jewish women has surpassed that of Arab women, when once the average for the Arabs was 9.1.
The number of countries desiring to have diplomatic relations with Israel has been rapidly increasing.
The growth of the State of Israel proves that G-d has not rejected the Jewish people.
53fd5ab5215e2323d925a221873cb90d:
Israel's establishment 69 years ago was an unprecedented event, leading to the foundation of the third Jewish commonwealth and the revival of the Hebrew language.
Israel's establishment and development are one of humanity's great success stories of the 20th century.
Israel's policies, especially under Benjamin Netanyahu as prime minister, attest to the state's departure from its fundamental founding principles.
Israel has retreated from the UN Partition Plan and has been torpedoing every effort to realize it.
Israel is denying the natural right of the Palestinian people to be masters of their own fate.
The declaration's key paragraph guarantees the democratic component of the Jewish and democratic state, but this promise has been replaced by an occupation regime in the territories.
The cornerstones of Israeli democracy — equality, the Basic Law on Human Dignity and Liberty and the separation of powers — have become loathsome to the government.
The nationalist State of Israel, with its fascist tendencies, scorns and derides the universal values that put man at the center.
Israeli society must fight to restore the vision of the Declaration of Independence and make it the state's vision once more.
aa10f3e32a030038a71cb243a38ff0a4:
Yom Ha’atzmaut is celebrated annually by Jewish people around the start of May.
Israel is seen as a nationalist bastion against attackers and haters by some.
Others view Israel as an open port to the world, a new springtime upon old wintered land.
Brexit and the rise of populist movements raise questions about the E.U.’s ability to foster globalization.
Zionism, the foundational ideology of Israel, offers a tension of multiple answers.
On one hand, Zionism is Israeli nationalism, seeking to secure existence through defensible borders and domestic prosperity.
On the other hand, the vision of Zionism was of an open society, not a closed one.
Theodor Herzl envisioned an independent Jewish state integrated into the orbit of European culture and community.
Herzl's Zionism argued that independence would create an end where the Jew finally would realize acceptance and respect within Europe.
Israel is already a part of the European community to a certain extent, being the EU's number one trading partner and holding membership in CERN.
There is a growing disparity between Israel and the E.U. on the peace process and relations with the Palestinians.
Some European voices have called for Israeli membership in the E.U.
The acceptance of Israel as an equal among Europeans will mark the fruition of the Zionist dream.
The European Union needs to resist the backward-looking reactionism of Brexit and other populist movements.
Globalization is not a threat to national cultures.
An integrated world, or at least one large segment of it, is a dream worth preserving.
86a2d4ef4d27d8bbff5e6642d9fdae65:
Jerusalem Mayor Nir Barkat believes conflict is part of Jerusalem's DNA and not a bug that needs to be resolved.
Jerusalem has a majority Jewish population of approximately 600,000 and a minority Arab population of about 250,000.
Mayor Barkat aims to keep Jerusalem united by ensuring that Arab residents do not want to see it divided.
Jerusalem is undergoing a renaissance of culture, including spirituality, music, art, sport, technology and more.

a3dd56970aa27248e9c4cabd3f5bd93b:
In 1967, the Six-Day War triggered widespread support for Israel in Western Europe, including the Netherlands, where there were massive blood drives, group prayers, solidarity rallies, and a successful bumper sticker campaign.
Today, Israel is a divisive issue in the Netherlands and across Western Europe, with mainstream media questioning Israel's right to exist and pro-Palestinian demonstrations often featuring anti-Semitic chants.
In Eastern Europe, Israel is now widely cherished as an ally and model for success, a shift from the communist era when mentioning Israel could lead to imprisonment.
The change in attitude towards Israel in Western Europe is attributed to factors such as the perceived lack of progress in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, demographic changes including the arrival of Muslim Arabs and Turks, and anti-Israel rhetoric by politicians seeking Muslim votes.
In Sweden, Israel's popularity in the 1960s was due to its perception as the underdog, but as Israel became more powerful, the Palestinians took on that role and the media became biased against Israel.
fd49a9933824772537242cadd5952266:
The Talmud states that only those living in the Land of Israel have a God, while those outside are comparable to someone without a God.
Rabbi Yaakov Yehoshua Falk suggests that the Land of Israel is qualitatively different from any other land in the world in that what happens to the Jewish People within it is a direct result of Divine activity and intervention.
Rabbi Shlomo Efraim Luntchitz notes that the fact that the Jews had enough to eat after allowing the land to lie fallow during the Sabbatical year demonstrated to them that Israel and her people were directly guided by the Divine.
Rabbi Yitzhak Arama sees in the Sabbatical-Jubilee cycle an allegory to ultimate world redemption, with the messianic era beginning at the end of the sixth millennium.
Rabbi Shlomo Riskin states that only in Israel do Jews have the potential to fully experience God both in the ritual and in the social, political and economic aspects of their lives.
1c420136e359a484ad24e0cda514ef56:
June 5–10, 1967, marks the 50th anniversary of the capture of the Old City during the Six Day War, which reunited Jerusalem and regained the heartland of Judea and Samaria.
The Gaza Strip and the Golan Heights were also conquered during the Six Day War.
The Jordanian occupation of Jerusalem from 1948-1967 aimed to destroy the State of Israel, not to establish a State of Palestine.
The idea of Palestinian Arab self-determination emerged with the formation of the PLO in 1964.
The highlands of Judea and Samaria are the cradle of Jewish civilization, not the coastal plain.
David established his capital in Jerusalem and brought the Holy Ark there.
After the death of King Solomon, his empire split into the Northern Kingdom of Israel and the Southern Kingdom of Judah.
The Assyrians defeated the Israelites and dispersed them, while the Babylonians dispersed the Judeans.
Jews remained in the Land of Israel during the Roman period and Ottoman Turk rule.
By the mid-19th century, Jews were the majority in Jerusalem.
The Israeli government hesitated to regain Judea and Samaria during the Six Day War due to expected backlash from Christian and Muslim authorities.
Israel regained control of all of Jerusalem and the Jews' biblical heartland during the Six Day War.
Israel sought to trade territory back to the Arabs for peace, but the Arabs rejected all overtures.
Jerusalem is now Israel's most populous city and is enjoying a renaissance as a religious, cultural, and high tech center.
9c0913e07bd7543aa32cb41de827df22:
President Reuven Rivlin opens Israel’s Jerusalem Day celebrations marking 50 years since the Six Day War and unification of the city.
Rivlin speaks of his memories of the battle for the city, and of the moments he heard the Old City had been secured under Israeli control.
“We gave our all for Jerusalem because we knew that on Jerusalem we must insist,” Rivlin says. “We will always insist on Jerusalem. There never has been, there never be any other reality. Here, in these stones, beats the heart of the Jewish People. Jerusalem is the heart of the State of Israel, and the Kotel is the heart of Jerusalem.”
The ceremony was attended by representatives of the IDF units who led the battle to liberate Jerusalem in 1967, IDF Chief of Staff Gadi Eisenkot and Jerusalem Mayor Nir Barkat.
Rivlin concludes his address by saying, “On the day of Jerusalem’s liberation, then defense minister Moshe Dayan wrote a note, and slotted it in between the stones of the Kotel: ‘May peace be upon Israel’. Today too, we continue to carry that prayer. May God give, and bring peace over Israel. ‘“Rejoice with Jerusalem, and be glad with her, all you who love her,’ Happy Jerusalem Day.”
d4735befe3adeb94e1183e929fb30d77:
Israel has made significant concessions to promote a second Arab Palestinian state, including signing the Oslo Accords and withdrawing from most of Judea and Samaria and the Gaza Strip.
Despite these concessions, Palestinians have not agreed to continue negotiations or stop incitement against Israel.
The international community and some Israeli politicians continue to insist on a two-state solution, despite the dangers posed by a Palestinian state.

8d9a359aaaee45099b5c2d180eb31e6c:
Israel celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the reunification of its capital city, Jerusalem, on Wednesday.
Israeli forces secured Jerusalem on June 7, 1967, after two days of fighting with Jordan.
Israel had sent a message to Jordan’s King Hussein asking him not to join the fighting, but Hussein chose to put his forces under the command of an Egyptian general.
Jordanian forces began firing against Israeli positions, and Israel did not attack Jordan until Jordanian forces broke into Israeli-held western Jerusalem and Radio Cairo reported that Mount Scopus was captured.
After two days of fighting, Israeli troops surrounded the Old City of Jerusalem, the last Arab position in the city.
At 9 AM the following morning, the Israeli cabinet approved an operation to retake the Old City.
Israeli forces entered through the Lion’s Gate and made their way to the Temple Mount, facing little resistance.
Israel’s Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said: This morning, the Israel Defense Forces liberated Jerusalem. We have united Jerusalem, the divided capital of Israel. We have returned to the holiest of our holy places, never to part from it again. To our Arab neighbors we extend, also at this hour – and with added emphasis at this hour – our hand in peace. And to our Christian and Muslim fellow citizens, we solemnly promise full religious freedom and rights. We did not come to Jerusalem for the sake of other peoples’ holy places, and not to interfere with the adherents of other faiths, but in order to safeguard its entirety, and to live there together with others, in unity.
When the Jordanian army first captured the Old City of Jerusalem in May 1948, they expelled all of its Jewish inhabitants, contrary to the dictates of international law.
From 1948 to 1967, Jordan destroyed over 50 ancient synagogues in the Old City, destroyed ancient Jewish graves on the Mount of Olives, and refused to allow Jews to visit their holy sites, many of which were desecrated.
Jordan also imposed restrictions on the city’s Christian population, including by controlling the materials taught in Christian schools and forbidding Christian charities and religious institutions from purchasing property.
4098990102a00a8e3a44ab0e43788eb5:

Several more Hamas officials are required to leave Qatar, but their identities and exact numbers remain unknown.
Those leaving Qatar will be dispersed to different countries such as Malaysia, Lebanon and Turkey.
Qatar's list of persona non grata Hamas members includes those involved in attempts to establish Hamas terror infrastructure in the West Bank.
Al-Arouri had worked for many years to establish Hamas cells in the West Bank in order to carry out terror attacks against Israeli targets.
Dodin was active in Hamas' West Bank headquarters, directing terror attacks against Israelis.
Dodin is also in charge of the issue of Hamas prisoners in Israel.
Hamas admitted that there were changes in the location of various officials whose names have not been disclosed.
Hamas denied that the request was made by Qatar following external pressure on it.
6aa72722450736da170cba182c5240d3:
Oraib al-Rantawi, director of Al-Quds Center for Political Studies, connected the escalation against Qatar to the May 20 Arab summit with US President Donald Trump in Riyadh.
Trump lumped Hamas with the Islamic State, Jabhat al-Nusra and Hezbollah in his terrorism list, while attending Arab Islamic leaders were quiet.
The four Arab countries that decided to boycott Qatar — namely Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Bahrain and Egypt — have not listed Hamas on their terror blacklist.
Egypt welcomed a delegation headed by Yahya Sinwar, the hawkish Gaza Hamas leader, and Saudi Arabia had in 2015 welcomed Khaled Meshaal, the head of Hamas’ political bureau.
The UAE’s favorite exiled Palestinian leader, Mohammed Dahlan, openly proclaims his good relationship with Hamas.
Omar Kullab, a Jordanian political analyst of Gaza origin, said that the visit to Egypt by the Hamas delegation was not a pleasant one.
Sinwar and his group were summoned to Cairo and were told point-blank that they have to quickly end their rule and hand over the reins of power in the Gaza Strip to the Ramallah-based authority.
Rantawi warned Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas and the Ramallah-based leadership not to get too excited about the developments between Hamas and the Arab world.
A PLO source in Ramallah said that the Palestinian leadership is very happy with the latest developments.
Jihad Abu Fallah, a senior producer with the UK-based, pro-Hamas Hiwar TV, believes that the Qatar crisis will have a negative effect on Hamas.
Many of Hamas’ leaders have already left Doha, and the newly elected head of the political bureau, Ismail Haniyeh, has retracted his decision to move from Gaza to Doha.
Rantawi called on Hamas to learn from the Palestinian exile experience in the past decades and reminded them that when the PLO was based in Tunis in the 1980s, they were forced to give in to international pressures in order to stay relevant and ensure that the world did not negotiate directly with the leadership in the occupied territories.
Rantawi believes that there are very few choices left for Hamas, which will not be able to find a safe haven even in Sudan.
If Hamas wants to get out of the bottleneck that is squeezing it, then it must find a way to return to the political umbrella of the PLO and give up its unilateral rule in the Gaza Strip.
Qatar has been heavily involved not only in supporting Hamas, but also in providing humanitarian aid to Palestinians, especially in the reconstruction effort after the Israeli wars on Gaza.
Palestinians are worried that as a result of this crisis, there will be an end to this vital lifeline.
d9ac21ee7ec045de4e0dc44aedded3ac:
Qatar's Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani said that Hamas is a "legitimate resistance movement" to the Arab world, while the United States views it as a terrorist group.
Qatar does not support Hamas, but supports the Palestinian people.
Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates, and Bahrain severed ties with Qatar last week, accusing it of sponsoring terrorism, including support of Hamas.

Hamas has engaged with a number of Arab states in the past week, especially with Egypt.
A delegation of Hamas officials, including the group's new leader, Yahya Sanwar, and the head of its Interior Ministry, Taufik Abu Naim, left the Gaza Strip for talks with Egyptian officials in Cairo.
Hamas said the meeting with Egyptian officials went well.

Hamas welcomed Al Thani's statements, saying that the comments were an expression of the values and principles characteristic of a prestigious country like Qatar.
c7a635b18275a846f398c8a7424f7e10:
Qatari Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani stated that Hamas is a legitimate resistance movement in the eyes of Arab countries.
Al-Thani confirmed that Hamas members are no longer in Qatar and its leadership is now in Palestine.
Al-Thani criticized Arab countries for accusing Qatar of supporting Hamas, as Hamas is not included in the Gulf Cooperation Council's list of terrorist organizations.
Hamas thanked Qatar for recognizing it as a legitimate resistance movement.
US President Donald Trump called on Qatar to stop funding terrorism, endorsing the decision of Gulf nations to ostracize Qatar.
d5d5b4620bf088c0659d550e7839a78d:
A high-level Hamas delegation returned home from Cairo after nine days of security and political talks intended to improve ties with Egypt.
Hamas denied reports in Arab media that an agreement had been signed between Cairo and Hamas.

Hamas and Egypt have had cool relations since Egypt’s Islamist president, Mohammed Morsi, was overthrown by the military in 2013.
Hamas leaders connected to its military branch left Qatar at the start of the diplomatic crisis, though its political leadership was allowed to remain in the country.
Hamas has been trying to convince Egypt that it is a reliable security partner.
Hamas made a gesture toward Egypt last month with a new policy document that dropped its longtime association with the Muslim Brotherhood and identified itself as a Palestinian movement fighting only against Israel.
Egypt has demanded Hamas turn over men it believes are responsible with working with ISIS in the Sinai, but Hamas has rejected the accusation against its operatives and refused to hand them over.
9311c04893ebd46161cf46bb1454e937:
Egypt has offered to provide electricity to the Gaza Strip if Hamas surrenders 17 wanted terrorists and shuts down its weapons smuggling tunnels.
Egypt will also supply Gazans with more freedom of movement if Hamas meets the conditions.
Egypt believes that Hamas's current vulnerabilities allow it to influence the terror group.
Egypt's objective is to neutralize Hamas as it struggles to get control of Sinai.

Hamas threatened to rain terror on the head of Israelis in response to the decision to cut electricity.
7e9871f77b6db092849cbc5da9f7e3db:
Egypt has offered to provide the Gaza Strip with more electricity in return for cooperation in counter-terrorism measures.
Israel's security cabinet approved a 40 per cent reduction in Israel's electricity supply to the besieged Gaza Strip.
Egypt has demanded Hamas hand over 17 men wanted by Cairo on terrorism charges, more protection by Hamas at the border, the cessation of alleged weapons smuggling into the Sinai Peninsula, and information on the movement of "elements" into Gaza via underground tunnels.

The power lines from Egypt that supply electricity to southern Gaza are often out of operation due to technical issues.
201b61dc8911d3dd448627649eb657a7:
Egypt has cancelled a planned visit by a delegation from the secular Fatah movement.
Hamas will visit Cairo for talks about mutual relations and easing the situation in the besieged Gaza Strip.

Fatah wants to undermine any meeting between Hamas and reformist Fatah leaders led by Mohamed Dahlan.

b666b3297d8860d32a3434ec8330cdb4:
Israel is in talks with Egypt and the European Union to head off an impending humanitarian disaster in the Gaza Strip amid an escalating dispute over electricity supply to the Hamas-run Palestinian enclave.

Netanyahu said Tuesday that Israel was not seeking a confrontation with Hamas.

Egypt also provided a small amount of power to Gaza, but those power lines have been malfunctioning.
According to Major General Yoav Mordechai, who heads COGAT, the Defense Ministry unit that administers civilian manners in the Palestinian territories, Israel currently supplies Gaza with 125 megawatts monthly — around 30 percent of what is needed to power Gaza for 24 hours a day.
After the new decision is implemented, Israel will supply Gaza with only 75 megawatts a month.
416d57f0a87dc24cd1879765a65c55b5:
The Egyptian government is keen to see Hamas resolve the issue of the Israeli soldiers it has held since the military offensive against the Gaza Strip in 2014.

Hamas will increase security measures on the border with Egypt in exchange for the "regular" opening of the Rafah Border Crossing and facilitating commercial exchange and movement.
Hamas is ready to meet and talk with any Palestinian, regardless of differences.
Hamas attacked Mahmoud Abbas, describing the Palestinian Authority and Fatah President as "the main obstacle ahead of reconciliation."
Hamas's new leader, Ismail Haniyeh, will be based in Gaza.

Hamas welcomed efforts, especially by Egypt, to agree a prisoner swap with Israel.
66050fb2bfc98d544b807d98e1e3d112:
Mohammed Dahlan, a fierce foe of Hamas, is reportedly forging an alliance with Hamas to jointly run Gaza.

Hamas representatives met with the Egyptian intelligence chief to discuss lifting the siege on Gaza.
Dahlan will chair a committee in charge of Gaza affairs, while Hamas will run internal affairs.

Hamas is facing a dilemma due to the Gulf crisis and the designation of Hamas and the Muslim Brotherhood as terrorist groups.
Egypt, the UAE, and Saudi Arabia are seeking to drive a wedge between Hamas and Qatar.
Dahlan is set to gain more power if the alliance with Hamas continues.
Israel may welcome Dahlan's involvement as he is seen as reliable, but it could lead to the separation of Gaza and the West Bank.
d0884b9d81dad5163e417bd26d0a46e9:
Hamas is distancing itself from Qatar and exploring ways to mend fences with Cairo and possibly strike an alliance with Mohammad Dahlan.
Qatar is trying to end its Gulf isolation and may have decided that its pro-Hamas positions have become an unnecessary liability.
Hamas saw a change in its top leadership recently, when Khaled Mishaal was replaced by Ismail Haniyeh.

Hamas was not included in the list of terrorist organisations, released by Saudi Arabia and its Gulf allies, as well as Egypt.

An agreement with Dahlan will result in the opening of the Rafah border crossing with Egypt and a quick easing of the humanitarian situation there.

Hamas is facing existential threats and rising disgruntlement among the people of the strip.

8eb708d5d6e9256f30d3edfab1ec3564:
Senior Hamas official Mousa Abu Marzouk met with Hezbollah Secretary-General Hassan Nasrallah in mid-June in Beirut.
Abu Marzouk met with Egyptian intelligence chief Khaled Fawzy in Cairo before traveling to Lebanon.
Hamas' armed wing has been urging the movement's political leadership to forge closer ties with Iran for armaments in preparation for a future military confrontation with Israel.
Tehran has renewed economic assistance to Hamas, albeit on a far smaller scale than in the past.
Egypt is making it virtually impossible to smuggle weapons and ammunition into Gaza.
Hamas' various factions are engaged in a fierce debate about its future.
Hamas' new approach calls for the political leadership to develop and maintain good relationships with anyone willing to accept the movement.
Hamas has promised Cairo that the organization would adhere to all the understandings recently reached with Egyptian intelligence and the National Security Ministry.
Hamas has also pledged not to smuggle ammunition and military equipment across the Egypt-Gaza border at Rafah.
The Egyptians told Hamas' new leader in Gaza, Yahya Sinwar, that it would only allow tanker trucks to enter Gaza and deliver diesel fuel to restart the only power station in Gaza under these conditions and with the supervision of former senior Fatah official Mohammed Dahlan.
Hamas understands that any deviation by the movement from these understandings will result in the closing of the Rafah border and the return of the existential threat to Hamas’ hold on power in light of the electricity crisis gripping Gaza.

39723c8d21fbd49077e79cf823ef0d30:
Qatar's support for Hamas has wavered due to political and economic pressure from Arab neighbours.
Hamas leaders have been slowly ejected from their headquarters in Doha, and continued support for Qatari construction in Gaza looks uncertain.
Hamas is seeking to repair ties with Egypt to avoid further political isolation and ease the power shortage in Gaza.
Hamas and Egyptian officials have discussed cooperating to shut down the flow of arms and militants to armed groups in the Sinai Peninsula loyal to Daesh.

aefb113fee1070c4604ac9a4b1872e95:

c632cbe86211845645cc975ccc8e508f:

e51aafde0fdeefca8ae19806975138e2:
Hamas is creating a 100-meter-wide (330-foot) buffer zone along the Egyptian border to combat extremists and improve ties with Cairo.

89fe592681398c430a14a67792f47154:

d8fd06a16954e7ec31102c659adaf327:

2415749f4df75e734f4d5e17c6ad0fa0:

07f7119e637278eb6daa609700850f41:

cf3375a726ae2dc22f098808e85e1c77:

fc22fbc70091d33f5b195192cedfcd42:
Hamas leader Ismail Haniya said recent talks in Egypt could lead to improving the humanitarian suffering in the Gaza Strip.

Relations between Gaza and Cairo have somewhat thawed in recent months.

94179736e2d5933b6117e0a41a91d0b2:
Hamas leader Ismail Haniya said recent talks in Egypt could lead to improving the humanitarian suffering in the impoverished Gaza Strip.
Hamas leaders, led by its Gaza head Yahya Sinwar, met with Egyptian officials in Cairo.

Hamas has had strained relations with Egypt since the overthrow of Mohammed Morsi, Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood president, in 2013.
Egypt began delivering a million liters of fuel to Gaza, temporarily easing a power crisis.
Hamas began building a security buffer zone along the Egyptian border to reduce smuggling.
acac1d67121b0f1f7434f6a31cfbba86:
Hamas chief Ismail Haniyeh hailed an era of new relations with Cairo that would ease the blockade of Gaza.

acbdc8d69ff78f857c49170c636f58de:

Hamas would retain control over Gaza's security, while Dahlan would handle its foreign relations.

Hamas has begun creating a security buffer zone along Gaza's border with Egypt.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El Sisi is expected to tell Abbas that Egypt cannot keep Gaza sealed off forever.
Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh lauded the new security co-ordination with Egypt.
Dahlan and Hamas reached several understandings, including Dahlan disbursing Dh$50 million (Dh183.7m) in UAE funds to the families of those killed in the Hamas-Fatah street fighting of 2006 and 2007.
86d7c2674e74f2020fdc0fe32e7464ca:
Hamas officials were photographed drinking Israeli products at a recent meeting, a week after endorsing the boycott campaign against Israel.

BDS co-founder Omar Barghouti said in 2014 that Palestinians have a right to “resistance by any means, including armed resistance.”

83fd28d372eeaec0b52d294506675261:

Cairo will continue to engage with all Palestinian factions, from Hamas to Jihad.

b8f8f821e6e574b6f075f1fa2ec2c8a7:

3bdf775719d82e74312b0427b7c08916: Egypt's armed forces killed 40 militants Friday after suicide bombing and shooting on an army check point in North Sinai.

Hamid allegedly killed an Israeli soldier and injured another in a vehicular ramming attack near Israel’s Ofra settlement in April.
Rights groups have warned that residents of Deir Abu Mashaal and Silwad have recently faced an escalating wave of “collective punishment” and restrictive measures on a routine basis.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has backed the punitive home demolitions since tensions escalated across the occupied Palestinian territory in late 2015.
Israeli authorities also refuse to return the bodies of the slain Palestinians to their families.
Israel continues construction of its illegal settlements across the West Bank.
55aff1896da4e8609dcaf2998f77fdd5:
Israel has demolished or sealed shut 41 Palestinian homes in the West Bank and East Jerusalem since October 2015 as a punishment to families.
Israel demolished 36 homes of Palestinians who allegedly attacked and killed Israelis, sealed shut with cement four others and welded shut a fifth.
16 homes were for families of Palestinians who are currently in Israeli custody while the rest for families whose sons or daughters were killed.
Israel has not taken any similar action against Israeli Jews who killed Palestinians in terror attacks.
1602c3b59e79ed5695b656f9d1161fd4:
Scores of Palestinians performed prayers outside the Shamasna home in the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood to show solidarity with the family facing imminent eviction.
Ekrima Sabri, head of the High Islamic Committee, claimed that the land of the Shamasna family home belongs to the family, not to Jews.
The Shamasna family has been told to evacuate the house willingly by August 9 or be forcibly removed and charged for the eviction costs.
The family has refused to leave their home.
Hundreds of Palestinians in Sheikh Jarrah are under threat of eviction by Israeli settlers groups.
Israeli settler plans have focused on taking control of the entire Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood and demolishing it to establish a massive Jewish settlement.
b066d3093871378669bba231a117f4d2:
Israeli forces demolished housing donated by the European Union (EU) in a Bedouin village in the southern occupied West Bank on Monday morning.
Khashem al-Daraj and Umm al-Kheir are among dozens of small communities located in the Masafer Yatta area, which falls within Israel’s “Firing Zone 918,” and inside the occupied West Bank’s Area C, the 62 percent of the West Bank under full Israeli civil and security control.
Palestinians are prohibited from entering firing zones without rarely granted permission from Israeli authorities.
Masafer Yatta residents were expelled at the time of the establishment of the firing zone in the 1970s and were eventually allowed back following a long court battle, but are under the constant threat of being expelled or seeing their homes demolished.
In 2016, the UN’s humanitarian coordinator in Palestine warned of a heightened risk of the forcible transfer of Bedouins in the occupied West Bank, including the community of Umm al-Kheir, amid an unprecedented surge in demolitions and land confiscations across the occupied territory this year.
The presence of around 3,000 Israeli settlers illegally living in the area has restricted Palestinian growth over the past decade while Israeli authorities reallocate local resources for settlement expansion.
04bdf9b1befd8833beb7c545ae782acc:
Israeli occupation forces demolished three Palestinian homes and facilities funded by the European Union (EU) in the Khashm Al-Darj village located in Hebron's southern city of Yatta.
The demolition left three families homeless.
Israeli forces have also handed other demolition orders to a number of the city's Palestinian residents under the pretext of "construction without permit".
The EU strongly condemned the demolition of the Palestinian structures in Area C, which the EU considers part of a future Palestinian state.
The EU has repeatedly raised the issue of the Israeli offensives on the buildings which it funds.
The EU called on Israel to stop its violations against Palestinians, stressing that the continuous demolition activities are "unacceptable".
In 2016 the occupation forces demolished €500 million worth of EU-funded projects and facilities in Area C.
According to the 1995 Oslo II Accord, the West Bank is divided into three areas: Area A which represents 18 per cent of the West Bank and is fully controlled by the Palestinian Authority (PA); Area B, which represents to 21 per cent of the West Bank, is under the PA's civilian control and Israeli security control; Area C, which represents 61 per cent of the West Bank, and lies under the full control of the Israeli government.
09c19033875535fdcc02be5d205d9cdf:
Palestinian Bedouin village of Al-Araqeeb has been destroyed by Israel 116 times since 2010.
Israel expects Bedouins to cover the cost of the destruction of their own homes.
Israel aims to destroy Bedouin culture and force them into townships.
Israel has passed laws to deny Bedouins land ownership rights.
Palestinian citizens of Israel live on only 3% of the land, despite making up 20% of the population.
Al-Araqeeb represents the ongoing struggle of Palestinians against Israeli colonial expansion.
fca3388ae03cd5e476a174ebc0842fe6:
An elderly Palestinian couple in East Jerusalem face eviction from their home of over 50 years.
The Israeli right-leaning settler group, the Israel Land Fund, found the previous owners of the house several years ago.
Under Israeli law, property proven to have been owned by Jews before 1948 can be reclaimed.
The Shamasnes lost their appeal to the Supreme Court four years ago.
The decision has sparked anger among the Arab population of East Jerusalem.
The couple’s son, Mohammed Shamasne, said he would struggle for the family property.
At least 44 other Arab families face the same threat of eviction in East Jerusalem.
The European Union missions in Jerusalem and Ramallah have called on the Israeli authorities to reconsider the evictions.
309382ab573c716ab3ba004304ea4ccf:
The Israeli military demolished the West Bank home of Omar Al-Abed, a Palestinian man who stabbed three Israelis to death in their home at a nearby Jewish settlement last month.
Omar Al-Abed, 19 years old, was shot and wounded by an off-duty soldier at the scene of the July 21 attack and later arrested.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called Omar Al-Abed a “beast” who was incited to hate Jews.
Police will charge five members of Omar Al-Abed’s family for failing to stop him from carrying out the stabbing.
Israel is pressing ahead with construction of an underground barrier along the border with the Gaza Strip to halt the threat of attack tunnels built by the Hamas militant group.
Talia Friedman, the daughter of the American ambassador to Israel, David Friedman, has immigrated to Israel and taken Israeli citizenship.
David Friedman, President Donald Trump’s former bankruptcy attorney, was appointed ambassador earlier this year.
4c21273c476f6457fc47ed41191e2a78:
Israeli forces demolished the home of a Palestinian who fatally stabbed three Israelis in a nearby Jewish settlement last month.
Clashes broke out between stone-throwing Palestinians and Israeli soldiers during the demolition, resulting in 12 Palestinians wounded by rubber bullets.
A Palestinian news cameraman was hit in the nose with a rubber bullet, despite video footage showing no clashes at the time and location.
Israel regularly demolishes the homes of Palestinian attackers as a deterrent against future violence, despite criticism from human rights groups who call it collective punishment.
Israeli authorities arrested the father, mother and three brothers of the attacker, suspecting they knew of his plans and failed to prevent the attack.
The attacker had spoken of Al-Aqsa and of dying as a martyr in a Facebook post before carrying out the attack.
The attack came amid heightened tensions over the Al-Aqsa mosque compound, which is considered highly sensitive by both Israelis and Palestinians.
Israel installed metal detectors at the entrance to the compound after three Arab Israelis shot dead two policemen, sparking protests and clashes that left seven Palestinians dead.
Israel removed the metal detectors, but Israeli police have been carrying out arrests linked to the unrest, with 72 Palestinians arrested in the past week, including 43 charged and still in custody.
1cb130888ec52429f7693034790a72c1:
Tel Aviv’s forces have flattened a house near the city of Ramallah in the West Bank, which belonged to a Palestinian youth accused by the regime of being behind a deadly stabbing attack against Israeli settlers.
Israeli military vehicles and bulldozers entered the area north of Ramallah at around 3:00 a.m. (0000 GMT) and surrounded the house, one floor of which was still under construction.
Tel Aviv claims that 19-year-old Omar al-Abed, who used to live there, had fatally stabbed three settlers in the nearby settlement of Neve Tsuf on July 21.
Abed has, since then, been placed under arrest.
His family members were also detained for what Israeli officials call their failure to prevent the alleged attack.
Israeli forces regularly target Palestinian villages in the occupied territories, tearing down structures and triggering often deadly clashes with the locals.
Anti-Israeli sentiment had reached new heights both among Palestinians and anti-Israel activists around the world over the regime’s three-day-long closure of the al-Aqsa Mosque’s compound in the occupied East Jerusalem al-Quds.
More than a dozen Palestinians have been killed in the ensuing tensions.
33034d4c06a015b13558a149fc1e5a50:
Israeli forces blew up the home of slain Palestinian Adel Hassan Ahmad Ankoush in the village of Deir Abu Mashaal in the central occupied West Bank.
Ankoush was killed by Israeli forces in June along with two other Palestinians after the three carried out a deadly shooting and stabbing attack in occupied East Jerusalem that left an Israeli border police officer dead.
Clashes erupted in the village between Palestinian youth and Israeli forces following the home demolition.
Ankoush’s home was sealed by Israeli forces last week, while the homes of Baraa Ibrahim Saleh, 18, and Osama Ahmad Atta, 19, who allegedly committed the attack along with Ankoush, were demolished.
A total of 22 people, the three mens’ family members, have been left homeless by the punitive demolitions in spite of not having been charged with any wrongdoing.
Isareli rights group, B’Tselem has condemned the practice of punitive home demolitions as “court-sanctioned revenge” carried out on family members who have not committed crimes, amounting to collective punishment.
87ee2ce63793a8bccde5994f94fc6e8c:
Israeli occupying forces have blown up the family home of Adel Ankoush, a slain Palestinian in the village of Deir Abu Mishal.
The house was raided early this morning and then rigged with explosives, while drones circled overhead.
The bombs detonated not only destroyed the foundations of the house, but also caused damage to five other homes in the vicinity.
The explosion started a fire in a neighbouring property and Palestinian Civil Defence firefighters were called to the scene to put out the flames.
Clashes subsequently broke out between residents and Israeli occupying forces, who responded by firing tear gas at protestors.
Last week, the homes of the two other Palestinians, who reportedly perpetrated the June attack, were also razed.
According to the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights, a total of 22 people who were family members of the alleged attackers have been left homeless.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has increased demolitions of Palestinian homes since 2015.
Human rights groups have repeatedly condemned such reprisals as a form of "collective punishment".
c5798064179790aefd273325daf00e81:
Israeli bulldozers demolished three houses belonging to Arab citizens near the Negev desert under the pretext of unlicensed construction.
The demolitions included a house in the village of Umm-Qabu near Tall Al-Sabe village as well as two others in the villages of Al-Atrach and Al-Sayyed that are not recognised by the Israeli occupation authorities.
Arab deputy in the Israeli Knesset, Said Al-Kharoumi, claims that the demolition campaign is just one in a series of recent fierce campaigns that aim mainly at harassing citizens and forcing them out of the area.
Israeli occupation forces blew up the house of a Palestinian family in the village of Deir Abu Mishal, northwest of occupied Ramallah.
Nearby houses suffered damages and one of them was set on fire as a result of the explosion.
Israeli forces razed Palestinian lands near Yattah south of the city, in order to expand a settlement built on Palestinian land.
009692d32b3484bc6f0baed7bc23ac57:
An Israeli court has ordered six residents of the unrecognized Palestinian village of Al-Araqeeb in the Negev to pay the government $541,000 for the cost of demolishing their homes 116 times since 2010.
Al-Araqeeb is one of 35 Bedouin Palestinian villages that the Israeli state refuses to recognize and offer any government assistance.
More than half of the approximately 160,000 Bedouins in the Negev reside in "unrecognized villages".
The Israeli courts have demanded compensation not only for the demolition of the homes but also for the cost of the state lawyers.
Representatives of the residents are considering an appeal, condemning the court's decision as a double punishment.
Human rights groups have criticized the move, arguing that the demolitions are illegal and that the state should provide shelter for the villagers instead of harassing them.
9cec3583952e9b22d5dab9f268b58282:
Israel demolishes Palestinian homes as a form of collective punishment and to achieve "demographic control" of occupied Palestinian territory.
Israel claims that demolishing homes of families of Palestinians who attack Israelis deters others from carrying out such attacks.
Israel has never demolished the homes of Jewish Israelis who have attacked Palestinian civilians.
Israel's High Court approved the demolition of the homes of three young Palestinians who carried out an attack at Damascus Gate in occupied Jerusalem.
Israel's Supreme Court decided not to demolish the homes of three Israelis convicted of brutally killing 16-year-old Muhammed Abu Khdair in 2014.
Israel demolishes homes of Palestinian resistance fighters and may also "seal" the homes of assailants.
Israel demands compensation from residents after demolishing their homes.
Some Palestinian homes are demolished due to a "planning policy" which is used to control the demography of the area.
Israel regularly approves plans for illegal settlements in occupied East Jerusalem, but denies permits to Palestinians for home extensions.
Israel has targeted the Bedouin Palestinians on both sides of the Green (1949 Armistice) Line for home demolitions.
Israel has targeted Palestinian schools in Jabal Al-Baba and Jubbet Al-Dhib, and confiscated the only source of power for a school in Abu Nuwar by removing its solar panels.
There is no evidence that demolishing homes of Palestinian attackers deters others.
Israel's demolition policy has failed to deter attacks and has increased hatred of Israel amongst Palestinians.
1db3451f7064a9b17254badeb24ae438:
Israel will evacuate 15 settler families from the Machpela House in Hebron, where they have been illegally squatting for a month.
The squatters have been given a week to leave before the IDF will be ordered to remove them by force.
The evacuation is in response to a petition by a group of Palestinian residents in Hebron.
The squatters entered the five-story building on July 25 and claim to have bought it legally, but authorities have not allowed them to remain there due to a lack of evidence.
In 2012, the same number of families briefly squatted in the building, but were removed after a one-week stay.
The Harhivi organization, which led the takeover of the Machpela House, said the state’s response was “unfounded and had no basis in law.”
The group argued that a missing registration document preventing the final authorization of the building’s purchase was not actually required to populate the building.
The squatters have been able to enter and exit the building freely for the past month, even enjoying heavy IDF protection.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ordered Defense Minister Avigdor Liberman to hold off on any eviction plans after the settlers first entered the building, but those efforts have likely failed.
c126d54f771d60917d95bce46f3235a8:
Israeli occupation forces have razed Palestinian land, including olive tree farms, around Salfit in the occupied West Bank.
The land belonged to the Islamic Awqaf (religious endowment) authorities.
The Israeli bulldozers targeted land in the area known locally as Khellat Al-Jamei.
Part of this area has already been developed by Israeli settlers to build a factory in the Ariel Industrial Zone.
Israel claims that this area is state land.
The Palestinian Ministry of Awqaf has tried several times to restore the land, but the Israelis rejected the requests and cracked down on activities on the ground.
The Palestinian residents of are being targeted directly by the Israeli occupation forces and settlers.
Salfit is important for Israel's illegal Jewish settlers.
The area contains more than 25 illegal settlement blocs which the occupation authorities are planning to expand.
The Israeli judicial system provides a legal fig leaf for the settlers' activities in the Salfit area.
f3eb4ce7408d464fe3eba8893f4f07eb:
Israeli police evicted a Palestinian family from their East Jerusalem home of over 53 years.
The eviction was criticized by the European Union, United Nations, and various Western governments.
The Shamasneh family was forcibly removed from their home by municipality officials backed by security guards.
The home was claimed by heirs of a Jewish family forced to abandon it in 1948.
Young Jewish men moved into the building after the Shamasneh family was evicted.
The United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA, will seek to support the family financially to find another home.
Israel took control of the area after the 1967 war and continued existing renting arrangements with Arab tenants.
A law allowing Jews to reclaim former homes or repurchase them has set up such conflicts.
Palestinians claim the evictions aim to alter East Jerusalem’s demography.
Israel says it is merely enforcing the law.
3520f58db854fea2b3421072ffa2724c:
Israeli police evicted a Palestinian family from their east Jerusalem home, making way for Israelis deemed the legal occupants.
The Shamasneh family has been fighting a court battle against Jewish claimants who said that the building was their family property, which they fled when east Jerusalem was occupied by Jordanian troops in the 1948 war.
Under Israeli law, if Jews can prove their families lived in east Jerusalem homes before the 1948 war they can demand that Israel's general custodian office release the property and return their "ownership rights".
In 2013 the Israeli Supreme Court ruled in favour of the Jewish claimants, who subsequently sold the property on.
It was the first eviction in the neighbourhood since 2009, according to Israeli anti-occupation group Peace Now.
Israel sees the city as its undivided capital, while the Palestinians want the eastern sector as their future capital.
Around 200,000 Israeli Jews now live in east Jerusalem in settlement homes considered illegal under international law.
Peace Now says the house is part of a larger process of establishing settlements in Sheikh Jarrah.
f5145c34e0fde00f6819c6cc9c663441:
Raba Abu al-Kiyan, the widow of Yakub who was shot to death by the Israel Police on January 18, lives in a tent next to the ruins of her home in the Bedouin village of Umm al-Hiran in the Negev.
On July 18, bulldozers returned to Umm al-Hiran and started to prepare the ground for the religious-Jewish community of Hiran, which is to be built on the ruins of the Bedouin village.
The district planning and building committee approved a plan for the evacuees of the Bedouin village to be moved to a provisional site for 15 years, in Hura in the southern Negev.
Raba's husband, Yakub, was a revered teacher who was called a "wicked terrorist" by Police Commissioner Roni Alsheich.
The Justice Ministry department that investigates the police has found a "grave operational failure" in the conduct of the police on January 18, and that "there was probably no terrorist event".
Raad Abu al-Kiyan, Yakub's nephew and the chairman of the village committee, continues to wage a struggle for the community's survival.
Raad says that the state has rewarded the Bedouin with murder and that they want to do things by force.
Raba says that she and her friends from Hebron live better than the Bedouin because they have land.
86ca56045abe4b07a7b16a51d183567a:
Israeli forces confiscated three agricultural vehicles owned by Palestinian farmers in the occupied Jordan Valley near Tubas city.
The machinery was confiscated under the pretext that the equipment is "not licensed for use and are being used on Israeli territory".
The occupation seeks to force the Palestinian farmers to leave their land in order to build new settlements.
Al-Ras Al-Ahmar is home to 22 Palestinian families surviving predominantly on agriculture.
International rights organisations consider the continuation of the Israeli campaign which targets Palestinians in the Jordan Valley as a violation of international humanitarian law.
c10cefa034bb916a2dc1a935a1f36f85:
The number of demolitions of Palestinian homes and other structures by Israeli authorities in occupied East Jerusalem is almost as high as 2016, which saw the highest number of demolitions since 2000.
At least 260 Palestinians living in 24 residential buildings in Sheikh Jarrah are under threat of eviction.
Israeli settlers are targeting densely populated Palestinian residential areas of East Jerusalem, including the Muslim and Christian quarters of the Old City, Silwan, Sheikh Jarrah, At-Tur (Mount of Olives), Wadi Joz, Ras Al-Amud and Jabal Al-Mukaber.
More than 3,000 Israeli settlers now live in these areas, either in houses expropriated using the Absentee Property Law, in buildings purchased from Palestinian owners, or in residences custom built and financed by settler organisations.
Israeli settlers use the courts to pursue the eviction of Palestinian families, based on claims the properties had been owned by Jewish individuals or associations prior to 1948.
In 2017 to date, up to and including August, Israeli authorities have demolished 107 structures in occupied East Jerusalem due to the lack of building permits.
The demolitions have resulted in the displacement of 179 people, including 107 children.
Four neighbourhoods, in particular, were "most heavily affected" – Jabal Al-Mukaber, Beit Hanina, Issawiya and Silwan – and, combined, accounted for 75 per cent of "demolition incidents documented this year and 70 per cent of all structures demolished" in 2017 to date.
The average number of people displaced in 2017 as a result of demolitions in East Jerusalem has slightly increased compared with the monthly average in 2016 (22.3 vs 21.2).
524c11b2a9691c372d0c311f4b9c8017:
Israeli forces demolished a Palestinian residential building in the village of al-Zayyem in the West Bank.
The demolition was carried out under the pretext that the building had been built without a permit.
The village of al-Zayyem is categorized as Area B, which is under Palestinian Civil Administration and where building permits are usually issued by local municipal councils.
Israeli authorities have demolished or seized 1,089 Palestinian-owned structures since the start of last year up until December 28.
The demolitions have left some 1,593 Palestinians homeless and affected the lives of another 7,101.
The UN notes that the “vast majority” of the Palestinian structures are destroyed or seized because the Israeli policies made it virtually impossible for Palestinians to obtain building permits.
Israeli demolitions of Palestinian homes and structures have raised alarm among diplomats and human rights groups over what they regard as the Tel Aviv regime’s continued violation of international law.
1dcb4a946cdc1f1a28b588fa65fc515e:
US Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis stated in June 2017 that the US is "not winning right now in Afghanistan."
President Trump has expressed frustration at the "lack of progress" in Afghanistan and suggested firing the top US commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson.
The Trump administration has delayed announcing a new US strategy for Afghanistan.
Afghanistan expert Almut Wieland-Karimi believes that the development of Afghanistan has been dominated by a military perspective and the political process has fallen by the wayside.
The Taliban carried out their deadliest attack in Kabul since 2001 on May 31, 2017, killing more than 150 people.
Afghan security forces are suffering heavy losses and currently control less than 60 percent of the country.
The US and its partners have no exit strategy from Afghanistan.
The UN has been keeping track of civilian casualties in Afghanistan since 2009, and the numbers are continually increasing.
The arrival of NATO troops in Afghanistan after the terror attacks of September 11, 2001, was the first time NATO's doctrine of "an attack on one is an attack on all" was put into action.
Afghanistan has constantly been in a state of war for almost four decades.
The current national unity government in Kabul, led by President Ashraf Ghani and Chief Executive Abdullah Abdullah, has been paralyzed by acute internal power struggles.
About 20 terror outfits are currently active in Afghanistan.
Pakistan, India, Iran, China, and Russia see Afghanistan as vital to their strategic, economic, and security interests.
There is an active struggle for allies on the Afghan battlefield.
9b663122ab8212af1e6e89136ad528dd:
Iran is expanding its influence in Afghanistan by cultivating networks of assassins and spies within the government.
Iran views the Taliban as a "loyal proxy" that can destabilize Afghanistan without causing it to collapse.
Iran's support for the Taliban emerged after a US airstrike killed Taliban leader Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, who had recently met with Iranian officials.
Iran has sent assassins, nurtured spies, and infiltrated police and government departments, especially in western provinces bordering Iran.
Afghan police have arrested 2,000 people in counterterrorism operations in the western Herat province, many of whom are criminals or rebels from Iran.
Iran-backed Taliban forces have attacked Farah, the capital of another western province, twice in the past year.
The withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan has emboldened the Taliban, according to Afghan officials.
Iran has a history of supporting Sunni terrorist groups, including al-Qaeda and ISIS, despite being a Shiite country.
Senior officials of the Sunni terrorist group Hamas attended the inauguration of Iranian President Hassan Rouhani in Tehran.
7eed08a2266eb16c6b44d397516976bd:
Iran has become a major player in Iraq, with its imports flooding Iraqi markets, Tehran-backed militias operating with impunity, and Iran dominating Iraqi politics through allied parliamentarians and militias.
Afghanistan may meet a similar fate to Iraq, becoming an Iranian fiefdom due to short-sighted American policies.
The Afghan Taliban insurgency is largely free from Pakistani control, financed by the drug trade and illicit mining in Afghanistan.
The Afghan Taliban has cultivated relations with Iran to counterbalance Pakistan.
Iran has provided funds, shelter, and weapons to the Afghan Taliban, aiding the group's operations in both the west and south of the country.
Iran has historically sponsored Afghan Shiite political groups and supported some mujahideen factions in the 1980s anti-Soviet jihad and the subsequent civil war.
The Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) uses these networks to recruit Afghan Shiites to fight in Syria to prop up the Assad regime.
Iran is aiding both the political and militant opposition to the present government in Afghanistan.
Iran's command over the Afghan economy is growing, with Iran becoming Afghanistan's largest trade partner in 2016.
India is assisting landlocked Afghanistan in developing an alternative trade corridor through the Iranian port of Chabahar.
Religion, language, and culture also provide Iran with soft power in Afghanistan.
A political settlement with the Afghan Taliban is the only way, other than a precipitous withdrawal, to end America's longest war.
A regional diplomatic process, including Iran, is also necessary for a political settlement in Afghanistan.
An enduring peace in Afghanistan is possible if and only if the United States uses its remaining years in the country to help Kabul and Islamabad develop the capacity and mechanisms to control their shared border and population flows along it.
A political settlement in Afghanistan, backed by regional states and anchored by Afghanistan-Pakistan cooperation, could release the region's latent cross-border trade potential.
There is a closing window of opportunity for Washington to provide an enduring framework for peace in Afghanistan after its eventual withdrawal.
GCC states, such as the UAE, have a role to support infrastructure development that bolsters Afghanistan's trade with and via Pakistan.
A campaign by Washington to make Islamabad the odd man out, however, raises the risk of Tehran's dominion extending further to the east.
5231edb5df0831572a1a444ec89ecbbb:
Iranian lawmaker Hossein Naqavi Hosseini warns of attempts by the US and Western governments to impair Iran-Afghanistan relations.
The US and Western governments are arming and supporting terrorist groups to interfere in Afghanistan's internal affairs.
Hosseini emphasizes the need for close cooperation between Iran and Afghanistan to counter hostile attempts.
Hosseini calls for concerted action by regional countries to combat terrorism in Afghanistan.
Hosseini deplores the muted response by the international community to a recent attack by insurgents on an Afghan village in which 50 civilians were killed.
36afbd2ee728bd550f05644106c02cb0:
Zamir Kabulov criticized Erik D. Prince's call to restore the British East India Company approach in Afghanistan, calling it a "colonial policy."
Akhtar Shakh Hamdard stated that the US views Afghanistan as a colony due to its natural resources and strategic location for reaching Iran.
The US has made an agreement with the Afghan government, making its military presence in the country legal.
The US spends about $20-25 billion on Afghanistan, which is a small amount compared to its annual military budget of $600 billion.
The US is primarily concerned about personnel losses in Afghanistan, which could lead to domestic protests.
75d174669a937368b497b152c099ccd7:
US President Donald Trump announced his Afghanistan strategy in a televised speech on Monday.
Trump admitted that his first instinct was to pull out US troops from Afghanistan but after months of deliberation he decided against it.
The government in Kabul, headed by President Ashraf Ghani, predictably lauded Trump's policy.
Trump refused to provide details about additional US troops he plans to dispatch to Afghanistan.
Trump slammed Pakistan for providing "safe havens" to Islamists and warned that US military aid to Islamabad could be cut.
Pakistani authorities will take Trump's Pakistan censure as Washington's weakness and get closer to Beijing.
Analysts say that without tackling the Pakistan problem, the conflict in Afghanistan will remain unresolved.
1ff1e9e085f58314012958c54ebeb430:
President Donald Trump has approved thousands of more troops for the Afghanistan war, along with an open-ended commitment to remain.
Trump's decision to escalate the war mirrors the actions of his predecessor, Democrat Barack Obama.
Trump has reversed his position on the Afghanistan war, which he previously called a "terrible mistake."
Trump's decision to increase the military presence in Afghanistan adds to the already long list of campaign promises he has either been unable to keep or on which he has changed his position.
Trump's defenders conceded that he has not delivered on his campaign promises but argued that he is still only in his first year.
f8bd87ccbe21395eaa8ed6e83cfc7513:
President Trump has ordered Defense Secretary Mattis to reconsider his plan for Afghanistan, but Mattis has not provided any alternatives.
Defense Secretary Mattis has described the 16-year war in Afghanistan as "16 one-year wars."
Trump will announce a new "path forward" for Afghanistan, which is expected to include sending more troops and continuing the current strategy.
Trump knows that the current strategy is not working, but he is under pressure from generals and the CIA to continue the war.
The war in Afghanistan is a racket that benefits the Afghan government, the U.S. military, and the CIA.
Trump considered a plan to privatize the war in Afghanistan, but it was rejected.
The U.S. is trying to withhold cash payments to the Pakistani military, but Pakistan has responded by closing down the U.S. supply route to Afghanistan.
The Afghan army is corrupt and ineffective, and the U.S. proxy government controls only a few major cities.
The Taliban and associated warlords control more than half of Afghanistan and continue to gain support.
ISIS in Afghanistan was originally formed by the Afghan National Directorate of Security, which is controlled by the CIA.
The U.S. military is engaged in tactical engagements in Afghanistan that have no lasting effect.
Any attempt to negotiate peace in Afghanistan would require extensive engagement with the Taliban, Pakistan, China, Russia, and Iran, but no one in Washington is willing to commit to that.
Trump's decision is likely to result in the continuation of the war in Afghanistan for several more years.
The only event that could change the situation is an incident with a large number of U.S. military casualties, which could lead to a groundswell of anti-war sentiment and pressure Congress to end the war.
4247ce27f2d817d7d5fd489b6fe6cdf3:
The U.S. and its NATO allies invaded Afghanistan in 2001 to oust the Taliban and deny militants a safe haven.
The U.S. initially refused help from NATO allies to defeat the Taliban, believing they could accomplish the task alone.
Pentagon chiefs criticized the U.S. for planning based on wishful thinking, assuming a strong central government in Afghanistan despite its history and lack of popular support.
Corrupt governance in Afghanistan, with extensive patronage networks and a lack of resources, hindered the country's development.
The U.S. spent $12 billion on eradication efforts, but Afghanistan now supplies around 90 percent of the world's opium, with the Taliban profiting from the illicit economy.
The U.S. spent $800 million on various projects to boost the Afghan economy, including a $6 million attempt to import Italian goats that went missing.
President Obama's troop surge in Afghanistan was undermined by a timeline for U.S. involvement, which critics say gave the Taliban time to regroup and erode the chances of their surrender.
54901abb432a340760b11a8e9539b4dc:
U.S. President Donald Trump criticized Pakistan, ordering it to stop giving sanctuary to "agents of chaos, violence and terror."
Pakistan has been at war with the Pakistani Taliban and homegrown extremists for years, but it has long tolerated the Afghan Taliban and the allied Haqqani network.
Pakistan has also struggled to combat other forms of extremism, including blasphemy, honor killings, and attacks on religious minorities.
The U.S. backed Pakistan during the Cold War and renewed the alliance after the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.
Pakistan's security apparatus has supported or turned a blind eye to extremist groups in Afghanistan and Kashmir, viewing them as a weapon against India.
Al-Qaida's top leaders, Osama Bin Laden and Ayman al-Zawahri, found refuge in Pakistan after the U.S. invaded Afghanistan.
U.S.-Pakistan tensions came to a head in 2011 when American commandos killed Bin Laden in a secret raid in Abbottabad, Pakistan.
Pakistan remains a major player in Afghanistan and will need to be on board if Trump hopes to end America's longest war.
Senior administration officials said ahead of Trump's speech that he was considering further cuts in aid to Pakistan unless it reins in the Taliban and the Haqqanis.
Pakistan could respond by revoking U.S. transit rights, shutting off the main supply route to U.S. forces in Afghanistan.
ebaea7d2977c1504e0f0d07197e51f10:
The U.S. and its NATO allies invaded Afghanistan in 2001 to oust the Taliban and deny militants a safe haven.
The U.S. initially refused help from NATO allies to defeat the Taliban, which allowed the Taliban to re-establish a foothold when U.S. forces were pulled out for the 2004 invasion of Iraq.
U.S. military planning in Afghanistan was based on wishful thinking, assuming that international troops would primarily focus on reconstruction and humanitarian aid after 2006, which was not the case.
The post-Taliban Afghan government was corrupt and lacked the resources and staff to function efficiently, rendering the country dependent on foreign assistance.
The U.S. spent $12 billion on eradication efforts to wipe out Afghanistan's opiate trade, but Afghanistan now supplies around 90 percent of the world's opium.
The U.S. spent $800 million on various projects and initiatives to boost the legitimate Afghan economy, including a $6 million project to import nine rare Italian goats that went missing.
President Obama's decision to set a timeline for U.S. involvement in Afghanistan undermined the mission, as it notified the Taliban how long they would have to hang on until the U.S. presence dwindled.
2dc16c6abc2959a082eada442540a362:
Afghanistan's strategic importance lies in its geography, which would allow groups like ISIS to establish a global caliphate if the U.S. withdrew forces.
Russia, Pakistan, and Iran would fund the Taliban and other terrorists to destabilize the pro-American government in Kabul if the U.S. left Afghanistan.
China would exploit Afghanistan's energy reserves and turn it into a corrupt patron state.
India would counter Pakistan's influence in Afghanistan, which could lead to conflict.
The U.S. should cut its losses in provinces like Helmand, where centralized policies have failed.
The Afghan government should secure arterial roads and improve education in Taliban-held areas.
The U.S. should pressure Pakistan to resist groups like the Haqqani network and facilitate Indian investment in Afghanistan.
The U.S. needs to empower young Americans to spend many years in Afghanistan applying local solutions.
The U.S. should focus on durable outcomes and be introspective in its approach to Afghanistan.
A sense of intellectual urgency must guide U.S. policymakers in Afghanistan.
ba9359337274f6826e2cfbea39b2f6b0:
U.S. President Donald Trump has many tools to pressure Pakistan to shut down alleged Afghan Taliban sanctuaries and arrest extremist leaders on its soil.
Trump's options include cutting off billions in annual military aid and downgrading Pakistan's status as a major non-NATO ally.
Trump has sought greater Indian engagement in Afghanistan, which has alarmed Pakistan.
Washington will first pursue an aggressive diplomatic effort to convince Pakistan to change its approach, and will only resort to military and financial measures if Islamabad fails to deliver.
Trump can designate Pakistan a "state sponsor of terrorism," which would trigger harsh U.S. sanctions.
